text: Patient: Sure. Sure. Doctor: You could go on before you uh, I think their trial is a, so it’s called a phase one trial. So what does that mean? So phase one traditionally was uh a dose-finding trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it determines how toxic things were. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: So with drugs what will often happen is a patient on a phase one where you came at an early stage you’d get a very low dose, probably too low to have toxicity but too low to be effective. And when you get to the high dose, it might be plenty to be effective but toxic, so you’d always sort of be Goldilocks at the end. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: For this, I’ve got a, I think for this, the trial, they were able to use the experience with Germany to say you probably could start about here. You don’t have to start way down here. And I don’t think it’s the same exactly like a regular drug phase one. So I think they’re kind of already in a in a sort of Goldilocks spot. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So that’s the only difference between you know in Germany everybody gets, they individualize it based on what they looked at is how much of the scan is your cancer taking off. They try, they, they describe what they said that if you took up that much material, you need to get this much. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So they give, they dose it based on how much of an exposure. Patient: Um hum.

text: Family Member: So in other words this third option, the chemo and the hormones—so when the chemo ends he’ll be getting radiation while he continues to get the hormone therapy. Doctor: Yeah and we give the chemo and the super hormones for three months. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And then give you about time to recover about six to eight weeks later. Then we do the radiation, uh which puts you at about sort of eight months, you know out, so then you’d have another; it’s a total of two years of hormones. Patient: Okay and then how frequently will my PSA be tested while I’m doing the chemo? Doctor: Every month. Patient: Okay, so you’ll know whether the castration is working or not with the hormone Family Member: After the three months of the chemo and hormone pills, how does the hormone deprivation continue? Is that – it starts now? Okay. Doctor: About every three months. Family Member: I’m sorry if you said this, but how long does the radiation go? Doctor: The radiation takes two months, coming to the hospital five days a week. I forget where you live. Patient: C___

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So my hope is that with time the fatigue will get better. Patient: Is that a good thing because the testosterone feeds cancer, right? Doctor: Well, it’s a good thing and a bad thing. It’s a double-edged sword. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But you and I made the decision when we first met after a discussion with Dr.__ as well – Dr. – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - um that the side effects from the hormone therapies were getting a little bit too much for you. Patient: Yes. Doctor: And your preference, which I agreed with at the time, was to stop the Lupron you get. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And given that your PSA level is very low, it was an investment point level, that you basically stop that, allow the testosterone to recover if you did good by itself, and then to monitor the PSA to see where that was at. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: From when I talk to people, first dose of chemo, most of the guys that I talk to, not a huge impact effect with nausea or, or anything. Um, it was the second or third that they really started to feel um - Doctor: In my experience, the first cycle is the hardest in some ways, ‘cuz you just don’t know what to expect. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, when am I gonna feel tired? They told me I’m going to have aches. They told me this, and then if it happens or some of it happens. Uh, so we’re trying to give you. But usually, that first cycle sorta gives you your pattern. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I felt good, and then I felt tired, and then I was really wiped out, I had to sleep a lot that week and then I felt really good and they had to do it again. (laughter) Patient: Where would I find that information? Healthcare Professional: Like the timing? Of the course -- Patient: No, the, eh, um. The aches and pains, I got a bunch of them. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Patient: Just, more -- But like the ridges on the nailbeds. ‘Cuz if I, if I notice something that is abnormal and say, “MMmmm.” I’m gonna make a phone call. But that’s gonna just doesn’t make sense. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. In your consent, it has adverse things to expect, what are more common, what are less common. It’s in your consent. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Yes, I know, my family doctor, same thing. Doctor: Yeah. So, I think you have to sign signature of patient here, right here. Patient: Okay Alright. text: Family Member: It’s the placebo thing? Doctor: Right. So, it’s placebo in the sense that the new drug is not guaranteed but it’s not placebo in the sense everybody gets chemo. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So, if there’s, you know, you’re guy one and you’re guy two you both get chemo no matter what. You might get drug and you might not. Patient: I got you, okay. Doctor: One of them you know. The other one you don’t. So, some it’s like oh, I’m just gonna get stuff infused in but we all kind of go gee, I wonder and it becomes a topic every time. The nurses try to guess. Everybody tries to guess. No one knows the answer except the people who actually hold the key. And then the other one is you know whether you get it or not because they just tell you okay, you’re just getting the chemo. But, the difference is you know everybody gets the chemo. That’s your standard drug. Nobody gets gipped out of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, a good question. It’s something that I have to always make sure people understand. At this stage in the game you should never be on a placebo only trial. Like it can never be either drug X or you’re crap out of luck. No, that’s never gonna happen. Okay? Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: And if anybody ever offers you that, that’s bad news. That’s just ethically wrong. So, we have a lot of watchdogs, safeguards, everybody’s looking to make sure that we don’t do something like that. Patient: Okay, Alright. Doctor: Yeah, keep going.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
